text: I think blogging has changed
tremendously over the past decade um one
we didn't really think of it consciously
as something that would be quite so
pervasive quite so influential so early
on when I started reading blogs I felt
like everybody in the community a few
dozen of us all read every other blog
every day um that'd be a little hard to
do when the other you know 100 million
or so show up to think gosh this is uh a
little bit more than we can read but
there was a very very strong sense of
community and what came from that was
the same feeling I have being in E
Village here in New York um where I live
and saying you know I know who my
neighbors are I know maybe I don't know
this person well but their face is
familiar to me um and in the same way
their voice was familiar and so your
norms for a community that size are
really um very thoughtful they're very
very consider it and you know
blogging somewhat to my dismay has
gotten a reputation as being a
free-for-all and people can say anything
do anything they're a lot they're really
unkind in the comments a lot of times
and those are because um as newer sites
came along or newer bloggers came along
they hadn't quite learned the lessons
that you get after 5 years 10 years of
blogging which are that you really want
to make sure you have a human connection
between the readers of your site between
you as a blogger and your readers um and
if you do those things you can preser
deserve the best elements of it so I
think we've lost a little bit of the
personal connection as certainly the
biggest blogs have been the ones that
Define people's perception of the medium
and those are essentially just more
broadcast or you know large scale
Publishers just like TV and radio and
newspapers where it was hard for them uh
to keep a relationship with their
readers I think um there's a lot of
conversations where journalists say what
what do we do about the authenticity
problem how do we confront it I think
think the fact that we you know that
that when I'm in the journalism world is
described as a problem is very telling
right and I think the the reality is
humans are very very well-wired to
evaluate the credibility of a source of
information all the time we do it night
and day and um there was this pretense
for a long time when journalism was
primarily a mass Market Endeavor that
you had to defend your credibility at
all times and that nobody would know
your bias was if you sufficiently hit it
and the thing is we've always known
we've always been able to see through
that and so you know I think step one
was
acknowledging how much people
wanted a real human voice that they
would be their own judge as to whether
there was a bias there and what the what
the background was and then the question
of credibility comes up all the time
what about if something you know that
CNN reads on air from Twitter isn't true
um then it gets corrected and that's
okay as it turns out a lot of what gets
reported gets corrected later you know
um I wish that they got it right the
first take every time both in blogs or
uh on on TV or in newspapers or whatever
but the reality is we don't know what
something means right away so the
immediate reporting of a fact is only
one step to figuring out what the truth
is and the analysis that comes later is
necessary to do that and if some of
those initial facts are fuzzy or
incorrect or even a lie a deliberate Act
of deception uh that actually happens
all the time you know I can think of a
million political examples where what
somebody's saying is actually the
opposite of what they're
doing I think a lot of people ask you
know is blogging over has it run its
course is this new thing cooler if
that's Facebook or Twitter um you will
know blogging has truly succeeded when
it becomes invisible and I think about
this a lot with um you know phone calls
I get introduced still at events as oh
he's a blogger and it feels a little bit
like being introduced as an emailer you
know or or a phone caller it's like
these are things we do every day you
don't think about them as a conscious
act it's just part of what you do to
communicate with the world we're still a
few years away from everybody realizing
that every time they take a phone a
phone camera picture and they post it up
somewhere they are acting as a blogger
every time you jot down a couple notes
online and share them with your friends
check out this link um that is blogging
and you know it doesn't have to go by
that name to be that that important Act
of documenting what you think matters to
you uh that fundamental Act of
connecting and sharing and building a
relationship with someone around the
things you share with them those are
empowering in a way that uh you know
when I used to work in in television or
the music industry I never could have
made a show on my own I never could have
made an album on my own I never could
have made a film on my own but a Blog I
can do entirely by myself and have as
the creative document of what I've done
that impulse will never go away there
will always be somebody that has
something to say that says I just want
to do it on myself all by myself and get
my word out there um and the fact that
people think that's possible that I talk
to young people and they say you know I
say what can you do with the book and
they're like oh you can read it you can
put cover on on it you can put it on a
shelf and I say what can you do with the
web and they say I can make it I can
create it that is the fundamental
difference that blogging brought about
as long as that's true and people feel
like that is a place that they can
create and express themselves blogging
is fine whether the name is there or not
people ask a lot about is the web
bringing us together it taking us apart
I think um culture has changed to the
point where shared experience is much
less common um you know as we talk today
it's very close to the 40th anniversary
of the landing on the moon and that was
one of the definitive Universal
experiences around the world everybody
had that experience whether it was on TV
radio newspaper there was a moment we
all shared those are fewer and fewer um
we place a priority saying it's more
human or personal to call our moms than
to chat with them on instant
messenger I don't know why we feel that
way uh they're just different well you
know we go to The Other Extreme we said
well a handwritten letter is the most
personal well that doesn't feel as
personal as a phone call to me but
that's supposed to be something valuable
because it's permanent well what if she
permanently archives an instant
messenger conversation does that go back
to being human again like the these
things are artifacts of Our Moment in
history we we are trained to teach that
something new is is inhumane and
personal and computer is and you know
technical and sterile and everything old
is warm and analog and expressive and I
don't feel that way I don't I don't feel
you know I have emails that I cherish
and value and I wish that we created
technologies that honored that you know
I don't want to throw away all my sms's
when I get a new phone I want to save
those somewhere but um
if Done Right these Technologies are
designed to help us communicate with
people we otherwise wouldn't be able to
with people we didn't know we had
something in common with they can help
us discover a
commonality um they haven't been
architected to create shared experiences
very well so we're losing a lot of our
cultural touchstones of something that
everybody knows a song everybody knows
the words to or you know a video
everybody's seen but they've done a good
job of all of us saying oh I saw this
funny YouTube video and I passed it
along and that is shared experience as
much as millions of people sitting
around watching you know the finale of
mash was you know decades ago or
watching the Super Bowl for its ads so I
think um Done Right these Technologies
bring us together the web is a tool for
connections that's what it's designed to
be I think the fact that a lot of people
don't feel that way has been because the
first attempts at a lot of social
networks or social software on the web
have been created by people that are bad
at building relationships both
personally and as architects of
communities um but we can fix that you
know the first decade of the web was
pretty bad at that but we're getting
better at making real connections online
um and I I think when it reaches its
potential the web will bind us together
in ways that television never could that
will make a phone or a handwritten
letter seem as you know rudimentary as
they
were
